notes.title: Note on Symmetric Elements
notes.content: Elements of the square matrix of type $a_{ij}$ and $a_{ji}$ are called symmetric elements, where $i \neq j$.

notes.title: Note on Trace of a Matrix
notes.content:
The **trace** of a square matrix $A$ is the sum of the elements of the main diagonal, denoted by $\text{tr}(A)$.

**Examples:**
Using the square matrices from the previous section:
$$ \text{tr}(B) = 1 + 4 = 5 $$
$$ \text{tr}(C) = 1 + 5 + 9 = 15 $$

notes.title: Note on Scalar Matrix
notes.content: Every scalar matrix is also a diagonal matrix.

notes.title: Note on Identity Matrix
notes.content: Every identity matrix is also a scalar matrix.

notes.title: Note on Triangular Matrix
notes.content: If a matrix is upper triangular or lower triangular then it is said to be a triangular matrix

notes.title: Note on Diagonal Matrices
notes.content: All the diagonal matrices are both upper triangular and lower triangular.

notes.title: Note on Transpose of Row/Column Matrix
notes.content: The transpose of a row matrix is a column matrix and vice-versa.

notes.title: Note on Transpose of Triangular Matrix
notes.content: The transpose of an upper triangular matrix is a lower triangular matrix and vice-versa.

notes.title: Note on Transpose of Diagonal Matrix
notes.content: All the diagonal matrices are self transposed.

notes.title: Note on Skew-Symmetric Matrix Diagonal Elements
notes.content: In skew-symmetric matrix, all the main diagonal elements are always zero.

notes.title: Note on Symmetric and Skew-Symmetric Matrix Formation
notes.content: If A is any square matrix then $A + A^t$ and $A-A^t$ are always symmetric and skew-symmetric matrices respectively.

notes.title: Note on Idempotent Matrix Powers
notes.content: If A is an idempotent matrix then $A^n = A, \forall n \in \text{N}$.

notes.title: Note on Matrix Multiplication
notes.content: Matrix multiplication will be discussed in detail in section 2.2.1.

notes.title: Note on Nilpotent Matrix Powers
notes.content:
If $A^p$ is a nilpotent matrix of index $p$ then $A^2 
eq O, A^3 
eq O, \dots A^{p-1} 
eq O$.

notes.title: Note on Square Null Matrices
notes.content: Square null matrices are nilpotent matrices of index 1.

notes.title: Note on Trace of Nilpotent Matrix
notes.content: The trace of nilpotent matrix is always zero.

notes.title: Properties of Involutory Matrix Powers
notes.content:
If $A$ is an involutory matrix (meaning $A^2 = I$), then for any natural number $k \in \mathbb{N}$:

**1. Even Powers equal the Identity Matrix:**
$$ A^2 = A^4 = A^6 = \dots = A^{2k} = I $$

**2. Odd Powers equal the Matrix itself:**
$$ A = A^3 = A^5 = \dots = A^{2k+1} = A $$

notes.title: Note on Involutory Matrix and Inverse
notes.content: If $A^2= I \implies A^{-1} (A^2) = A^{-1}(I) \implies A = A^{-1}$

notes.title: Note on Idempotent Matrix Period
notes.content: Idempotent matrix is a periodic matrix of period 1.

notes.title: Note on Hermitian Matrix Transpose
notes.content: If A is any square matrix over C then $(\bar{A})^t = (A^t)$.

notes.title: Note on Hermitian Matrix Elements
notes.content: In Hermitian matrix elements of the main diagonal are always real numbers, and symmetric elements are conjugate of each other.

notes.title: Note on Hermitian and Skew-Hermitian Matrix Combinations
notes.content: If A is any square matrix over C, then matrices $A+ (\bar{A})^t$ and $A-(\bar{A})^t$ are always Hermitian and Skew-Hermitian respectively.

notes.title: Note on Skew Hermitian Matrix Elements
notes.content: In Skew Hermitian matrix, elements of the main diagonal are either purely imaginary or zero. Furthermore, the symmetric elements are additive inverses of each other if they are real or same in case of imaginary numbers.

notes.title: Note on Determinant of Triangular Matrices
notes.content: The determinant of diagonal, scalar, identity, upper triangular & and lower triangular matrices is the product of the elements of the main diagonal.

subtopics.title: The values of the determinants of any square matrix $A$ and its transpose are always the same.
The interchange of any two rows or columns of a square matrix $A$ changes the sign of its determinant without altering its numerical value.
If two rows or columns of a square matrix are identical, then its determinant is zero.
If all the elements of a row or column of a square matrix are zero, then its determinant is zero.
If every element in a row or column of a square matrix $A$ is multiplied by the same number $k$, then $|A|$ gets multiplied by $k$.
If every element of a row or column of a square matrix $A$ is expressed as the sum of two terms then $|A|$ can be expressed as the sum of determinants of two matrices...
If the elements of one row or column of a square matrix $A$ are $k$ times the corresponding elements of its another row or column then $|A| = 0$.
If to each element of a row or column of a square matrix A is added, a constant multiple of the corresponding element of another row or column then the value of |A| is unaltered.

notes.title: Note on Rank and Determinant
notes.content: If $|A| \neq 0$, then rank $(A)$ = order of the matrix A.

notes.title: Note on Rank Value
notes.content: Rank $(A) \ge 0$.

notes.title: Note on Rank of Row/Column Matrix
notes.content: Rank of a non-zero row or column matrix is 1.

notes.title: Note on Homogeneous System Solutions
notes.content:
If $AX = O$ is homogenous system of linear equations with “n” unknowns, then:
(i) it has only trivial solution if rank of $A = n$ or $|A| \neq 0$
(ii) it has trivial as well as infinitely many non-trivial solutions iff rank $(A) < n$ or $|A| = 0$

sections.title: Applications & Advanced Properties
sections.intro: Determinants are not just calculation tools; they are used to solve geometric problems and define special matrix types.

subtopics.title: Geometric Applications of Determinants
subtopics.content: Determinants can be used to find the area of a triangle and check if points are collinear.

notes.title: Area of a Triangle
notes.content:
The area of a triangle with vertices $(x_1, y_1)$, $(x_2, y_2)$, and $(x_3, y_3)$ is given by:
$$ \text{Area} = \frac{1}{2} \begin{vmatrix} x_1 & y_1 & 1 \\ x_2 & y_2 & 1 \\ x_3 & y_3 & 1 \end{vmatrix} $$
If the value is negative, we take the absolute value.

notes.title: Condition of Collinearity
notes.content:
Three points are collinear (lie on the same line) if the area of the triangle formed by them is **zero**.
$$ \begin{vmatrix} x_1 & y_1 & 1 \\ x_2 & y_2 & 1 \\ x_3 & y_3 & 1 \end{vmatrix} = 0 $$

exercises.title: Example: Find the Area
problems: Find the area of the triangle with vertices $A(1, 2)$, $B(4, 2)$, and $C(3, 5)$.

subtopics.title: Advanced Matrix Types
subtopics.content: Definitions of Orthogonal, Unitary, and Conjugate matrices.

notes.title: Conjugate of a Matrix
notes.content: The matrix obtained by replacing each element with its complex conjugate (e.g., $3+i \to 3-i$) is called the **Conjugate Matrix**, denoted by $\bar{A}$.

notes.title: Orthogonal Matrix
notes.content: A square real matrix $A$ is orthogonal if $A A^t = I$. This implies $A^t = A^{-1}$.

notes.title: Unitary Matrix
notes.content: A square complex matrix $A$ is unitary if $(\bar{A})^t A = I$. This implies $(\bar{A})^t = A^{-1}$.

subtopics.title: Word Problems (Modeling)
subtopics.content: Using matrices to solve real-world problems.

exercises.title: Example: Investment Problem
problems: A sum of $10,000 is invested in two schemes paying 5% and 7% interest respectively. If total interest is $600, find the amount in each.

**Modeling:** Let investments be $x$ and $y$. Then:
1) $x + y = 10000$
2) $0.05x + 0.07y = 600$
We can write this as $AX=B$ and solve using Matrix Inversion or Cramer's Rule.
